Before signing up for Amazon Music HD you should  review the system requirements if you suspect your home wifi is underpowered.
title: Update 12/6/19. See bottom  of review. Blown away by Amazon Music HD and Adobe  Atmos

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Drew Lankford
content: The hype is real with this.  It sounds incredible for it's size and after putting it side by side with our home pod, the homepod got demolished in terms of bass output and clarity when cranked and I would say ***AFTER A VERY NECESSARY FIRMWARE UPDATE ON THE ECHO STUDIO*** they're about on par with sound quality/clarity at lower/medium volume. I say that update in bold because out of the box, as you may have heard/read, the 3D audio setting on the Studio makes the sound worse unless you're listening to 3D audio.  More than that though, the option to disable 3D audio is not even in the audio settings. You have to actually TELL the device to update and there were 3 updates mine had to do to get to the most recent firmware version. Once that was taken care of though, not only was the 3D audio toggle switch in the audio options but the sound quality of non 3D audio music was WAY better.  They must have heard the complaints about it not sounding very good with 3D turned on and fixed whatever was going on because now, you can hear the quality and clarity DROP when you disable 3D. I dont like the fact that I had to go to forums to figure out that I needed a firmware update AND that I had to use voice commands to do this.  These things should be in the Alexa app both telling you there's a software or firmware update AND the option to always keep it up to date.  The thing is always connected to the internet so I don't think that's too much to ask.  All my other devices, smart TV and game consoles manage to do this so Amazon need to take action.
title: HUGE sound from a tiny little object

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Dan
content: This is a nicely made and presented product. I had high hopes for it, but it is a bit disappointing. Here's why... Sitting close, it sounds full and powerful. Moving away the impact drops off very quickly. Also, as you turn up the volume, the amplifiers dynamics processing is very audible and the bass is reduced noticeably. It kind of comes in and out, so it loses "punch". Also, I am not a fan of the imaging or soundstage. Seems pretty point source to me and flat. I know Amazon has specially encoded "Atmos" tracks to show off the soundstage, but that not what I'm listening to 99.9% of the time. I find myself not using it most of the time... it just seems a little fake sounding. I like the original Echo device better even though it is not in the same class output or bass wise, it is more listenable and truthful to me. I can accept its shortcomings because it more honest sounding. The other HUGE issue to me is the inability of voice recognition circuitry to work when it doing what it's designed to do... play loudly. You end up screaming at it. I've used much better implementations of the Echo solution that can understand voice commands when a lot is more going on in the room, sound wise. I know I could use two of them and add a sub, but at that point might as well get a real hi-fi and an echo dot for $22.00 and call it a day. Hey, you guys asked...
title: Good, but not great.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Darrell Fichtl
content: At 88 I'm a skeptic and a picky sob. I also sometimes question the validity of some of the reviews. So let's get the validity question out of the skepticism. 1. I have a first-class commercial radio license. 2. I was the regional expert for voice and data transmission when I retired from AT&T in 1983. 3. I was a computer programmer for many years and owned a shareware business before that business went up in smoke due to increased data speeds. 4. I had a high fidelity system in my home when your parents were probably in diapers. So, with all that out of the way, I'll have to say I was totally pleased with the performance and the sound quality that filled the room. My first surprise, when I picked it up from the porch, was the weight. I really wasn't expecting that. In addition, I was totally surprised at the size and the really cool, pardon the expression, of the appearance of the instrument.. I chose that word carefully because it isn't just a speaker, it truly is an instrument.
title: Absolutely outstanding

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Joe F.
content: The speaker function is outstanding with absolutely great sound but unfortunately the software to make it work as a sound bar replacement isn't there yet. When connected with a mini-optical cable to a 2019 Samsung Series 8 TV, the behavior is almost possessed and I don't know if the issue is with the Echo Studio, the Samsung TV or both. Sometimes the sound is really great but then it will suddenly just quit completely. It won't work again until you disconnect and reconnect the cables. Searching online, this seems to be a fairly common issue.  Other times, the sound will suddenly become what I would describe as fuzzed or distorted.  Disconnect and reconnect and it will work fine again. My TV has a crap shoot of a time selecting the audio source when connected to the Echo Studio. Sometimes it works normally; select OPTICAL and it comes out the Echo Studio, select TV and it comes out of the TV speakers. Other times, it is coming out of the Echo Studio regardless of the source selected. Select OPTICAL and it comes out the Echo Studio, select TV and it comes out both the TV speakers and the Echo Studio (slightly delayed just to be more annoying.) If connected by Bluetooth, that seems to work with both the audio and the source selection but it defeats the purpose of using the optical cable for the best sound quality. Also, the only way to control the volume when connected with either the optical cable or Bluetooth is by using the hardware buttons on the Echo Studio. The Samsung TV doesn't recognize the Echo Studio as a known sound bar when connected to the optical cable and can't set up the remote; so no remote control of the volume. Even stranger, when connected via Bluetooth or optical, the voice commands via Alexa, while appearing to work, don't actually change the volume. When streaming music, the voice commands work perfectly. I don't know if the problem is the the TV or the Echo Studio but the two definitely don't play nicely together. I'm hoping that a software update by one or both will finally give me the sound bar I was hoping for.  I do love the sound as a speaker though. It is everything I was expecting.
title: Awesome sound but don't expect to use it as a sound bar.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Eflopez
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. 10 Stars out of 5. How in the world are these only $199!!! Buy two and you have the perfect surround sound home audio set up!!!! Picked one up from the Amazon 4-Star store in Berkeley, CA. The sales associate sold me before the Echo Studio was even released. Was at the store location at opening ready to buy one! These are the perfect gift for that loved one that has been looking to upgrade their home sound system. Easy set up and flawless use since day one. Pros: Everything you can ask for in a home surround sound system and more. (Recommend getting two for the main room use.) Cons: Limited quantity available on release date. (Get then as fast as you can.) Have the Sonos one and a Sonos sub at home. I will be passing my Sonos set up to my brother. With Alexa integrated into the device and easy use with my existing echo devices, I have no personal need for Sonos.
title: Only Pros!!! Must get!

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: A J
content: Previous echos - the sound has only been adequate. Sure, you could plug an amp and speakers into the audio out, but then you have to either leave those powered on, or hunt around for remotes, rather than just voice command. Quiescent power draw with the Echo Studio is about 3.6W from the wall (kill-a-watt meter).  Thats about $4 a year in my location, so leaving it powered is an easy decision. It was a bit of a pain to set it up on day one.  The iphone app couldn't remap the wake word, or show volume properly.  Android was fine though.  The Studio itself was easy to do basic setup, even with it requiring an immediate (automatic) update. Overall for the convenience this is now our main music player
title: 3.6W on Idle

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Cast Iron love
content: 1st thoughts - it's clear, heavy and is not producing the sound I thought it should produce. Then I found out why Went to connect my AUX cable and run my computer though it, sounds great. Then I went to surf a few pages, wound up on Instagram and boom, there it was, the music on someone's post was coming through the way I thought it should sound. Bit rate and Decibel level of the music or move being pushed to the speaker matters. If you use your speaker with a DVD player, OMG, the bass shakes the area it's in. Only issues I have with it, and I know why, is that it won't pair with my older Echo show, something with the hardware. ok, no problem,
title: This little mofo is weird in a good way

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: dh
content: This is an exceptional product. For the small package that its in, the sound is detailed. It's in stereo. And it provides bass that is crisp and clear. I immediately started listening to music and was very pleased with the performance. I've linked SXM and Amazon Music and have listened to a variety of types of music via these channels. in addition, the volume buttons have proven very useful.  On top of this you get the exceptional Alexa voice app and all that it can do. I am going to buy one for each of my Christmas gift list. (My fear is they sell out!)
title: Amazon has a winner on its hands!

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: David
content: This speaker puts out some excellent sound from such a small package - when it decides to put out sound. Setup was easily as always with Amazon devices, and after a quick google I paired with a fire tv stick 4k. Now that it was ready to go, I wanted to try listening to music on it. Tell Alexa to play music ... nothing. Try again ... nothing. Try command I've used on my other Echo ... nothing. I went on the spotify app and selected play music to the Echo Studio, and finally, excellent, rich sound. 15 minutes of a playlist going, and then audio stops. Start music again from the spotify app, everything is great, until a few songs later and audio stops. I also connected a toslink from the TV to the Echo Studio line-in. Turn on the TV, and the Echo Studio switches to playing audio from the TV ... until it decides to stop playing all audio. I could not find any commands to get audio back up again. Turn off the TV and back on, and great, it's fixed, and 20 minutes later ... you get the picture. Alexa's voice also had a weird glitch where she would speak in a extremely slow stutter. Not all of the time, just randomly. The Echo studio produces clear, room filling sound with respectable base. If you're looking for stereo sound, get two, as a single just can't replicate a stereo set up. I would love to love it, but it is just not there yet. I hope Amazon can figure out these glitches as the Echo Studio is a great speaker at a good price.
title: Great smart speaker that just isn't ready for showtime yet

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: D. Burchfield
content: Fantastic sound and easy set up. Very impressed with the whole package!
title: Better than Bose.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: James R. Garrett
content: I was really interested in this technology when I first read about it, so naturally got in line for one of the first units to ship.  I have five of these Echo speakers scattered about the house and yard but looking to complete my living room stereo system.  Sounded pretty good out of the box till I paired it with my Echo Plus and began to notice the obvious difference in sound quality in the upper range. The Studio Alexa voice has a distinctively tinny sound compared to the Echo Plus.  Strike one.  Strike two was the erratic response behavior...that one’s a little more subtle and a bit more difficult to pin down.  Not exactly sure why, but it seems to lag or sometimes didn’t respond at all.  Could not really detect any benefit to the 3D FX and the bass response isn’t all that great at lower volumes.  I already have the Echo Sub-Woofer which I HIGHLY recommend.  So, why do I need this thing?  UPDATE: I just added my new Echo Plus 3rd Gen to the living room stereo group and the quality is exceptional.  I already have my return ticket, the Echo Studio will be boxed and headed back tomorrow.  Let’s see, how many strikes is that...Ok, I lost track.  Anyway, Echo Studio. YOU’RE OUT!
title: Not What Its Cracked Up To Be

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Terry Gavin
content: This is a phenomenal speaker; however, one suggestion, Amazon: feature an HD light. Seeing that we're paying for HD music, this speaker should indicate when an HD song appears, just like Dragonfly does. In addition, there should be different shades on this HD light to indicate 96, 48, or 24.
title: Almost There

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Erwin
content: Similar to many others, we have Echos strewn throughout the house and in the living room we added the Echo Studio to the existing Fire Cube TV and Echo Dot. Originally, sound for the Fire Cube TV went through the TV via HDMI to a set of speakers. The Echo Dot was connected to a different set of speakers. I thought I could use the Echo Studio to completely replace the speakers needed. Overall, it did not work out as great as planned because of how the Echo Studio handles the 3.5mm input. It needs a certain volume level to keep it on. Frustrating when watching a program/movie and there is a quiet part and next thing you know is you missed the previous dialogue. Just plain frustrating! I'll go through my observations: Sound was full and good enough for us and since that is subjective (know many audiophiles), it gets 5 stars. Tastes may vary. Integration with Fire Cube TV was painful, but figured it out. Instructions/documentation was useless. We have a smart home with over 20 various smart devices (echoes, cameras, lights, etc.) and all successfully connect via Alexa, so I am well-versed in setting up devices in our environment. This was painful. As I mentioned, I wanted to replace the external speakers and have multiple inputs into the TV, not just the Fire Cube TV. I thought the Echo Studio could be that solution for an echo device and a single speaker output for any media on the TV. With the 3.5mm,/TOS jack, it can, but with that one issue of if the volume level dips down too low, the Echo Studio just stops. We also have the Echo Connect for our phones and whenever a call came in, we'd lose audio. For that we turn off the "incoming Call Ringer" under "Sounds" in the Alexa app for this device and many others. I have contemplated just turning on "Do Not Disturb" and mute this since it seems that anything that turns on the Echo Studio will interrupt the media coming from the TV. It seems the only solution when watching media on the TV is to keep the volume up on the TV very high and manage the volume from the Echo Studio, which requires us to get up and change it. Since we are muting it, we can remote from a device, but that is too cumbersome; it's easier to just get up. The Amazon devices in the living room are now only the Fire Cube TV and Echo Studio. Overall, it works, but that constant managing volume levels is so frustrating since at times we are watching live TV and not able to rewind 10-15 seconds. 2 stars.
title: Frustrating for my use case

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Captain Fantastic
content: I’m a bit disappointed. Sound quality is good, but not the fully immersive experience I expected, even with Amazon suggested HD songs. Used paired with a subwoofer. Volume is also an issue. Doesn’t get as loud as a standard Echo. After buying I see that a paired system is what really works, which frustrates me because Amazon marketed as a lower price alternative to Sonos, but if I have to buy two, then I’m right within the Sonos range.  Amazon should be more obvious about the paired system as the “immersive experience”. One by itself doesn’t cut it.
title: One unit doesn’t cut it, needs two for the “immersive” experience

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Shell
content: My phone's or any other bluetooth source WILL NOT connect. Amazon block the bluetooth so that wonderful Echo Studio - High-fidelity (so called smart speaker) does not have the ability to pair with ANY devices outside of the Alexa App. SO IT'S NOT A BLUETOOTH SPEAKER. IT'S AN ALEXA APP SPEAKER ONLY! This really sucks! A better purchase would be a real BLUETOOTH SPEAKER that has Alexa enabled...
title: I hate the fact that IT'S NOT A BLUETOOTH SPEAKER.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: wisconsin wildman
content: Ok sounding unit.  Not sure it’s worth the price. I won’t attempt to listen in 3D or HD as I’m not going to want to spend the extra later.  Huge volume differences between services, but could be the service.  Seems to have to be turned up high to get decent sound.  In an apartment living room that’s about 17 feet long by 15 wide.  Alone it’s sound isn’t that loud (or great) Crazy thing that when linked with an echo dot 3rd gen, it fills room better (the studio on far end of room, the dot on the opposite end, studio at volume 5, dot volume 6). One of my peeves of this whole echo system is equalizer settings and volume settings come and go. I do hear some depth using tune in as my streaming service.  It’s better than the dot alone obviously,but without the dot, it seems a bit blah.  I understand the other reviews about it being kind of vocal lacking. I don’t plan on using it in a home theater type st up as I already have a bose sound bar I’m quite content with that sounds better than this unit.  Similar prices also. I do enjoy linking my five devices (studio, regular echo gen 3, and three dots around the apartment) for full apartment music.  Might be the only reason I keep the studio as I’m not that much of a fan.  It’s kind of well, unimpressive, but gives a little extra “oomph” to the whole bunch together. As far as Bluetooth, I find it painful to pair versus any other Bluetooth device.  I’ll probably only use it for streaming services and use my Bluetooth speakers for that purpose.  This applies to all my echos. I’ve never listened to a Sonos or the expensive Apple speaker, so I haven’t a clue what to compare it to.  I’ve been more impressed by Bluetooth speakers that I have when I first heard them.  I’ve had a few by the likes of bose, ue, and Soundcore. When it comes to speakers, the echo studio is ok.  I’ll keep it because of the alexa operation, but have heard better.  There’s not a huge “wow” factor for me.  Very surprised it’s not better claiming 330 watts. Kind of like finding an amazing pizza at my advancing age......
title: Not sure if it’s a keeper (Ok, it’s growing on me)

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Charles E. Wegrzyn
content: I don't have a clue why anyone would say it doesn't play music nor work. This thing plugged into my wireless network as easily as all the other Alexa devices. Music playback is better - much better - than the other Echo devices (because of the speakers). It does very well with Amazon HD music giving me a sense of directionality!  It is integrated with my HiFi system and TV all without a lot of extra effort. Definitely worth it....
title: What's not to like?

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Adrian
content: I waited 5 weeks to receive this speaker. Which I wasn’t told until after I placed the pre-order that it would take this long. But that’s beside the point. I’ve read the interesting Amazon reviews on the Echo Studio while being patient and I still knew it was worth at least trying this speaker out. I’m not an audiophile, but I have good hearing. I’m not exaggerating when I say, the 3rd generation Echo Dot (yes the dot) paired with or without a sub is 10x better of an experience then this Echo Studio. The Echo Studio sounds like 3 instruments trying to be a team but are clearly hung over. Man the sound is so hollow and muffled. It’s like they put someone inside an empty Costco warehouse, ducked taped the man’s mouth and told him to annunciate the ABC’s but meanwhile it just sounds like Ariana Grande singing a verse. Just noise. I turned down the bass, turned it back up, turned up the treble, tried the spatial audio sound thingamajig. Placed it in the middle of the room, in a corner, directly in front of me. In summation, I encourage you to spend $200 on this because you can always return it. Don’t take my word for it, I’m just telling you my personal experience. I have 3 third generation echo dots throughout my home and those have a RICH sound that I’m very impressed by. Even just one by itself. I went to Amazon 4 Star store in Berkeley yesterday and tried the Echo and Echo Plus..... literally the Echo Dot was still the winner for me. It’s $24 right now and I’m laughing at how size doesn’t matter. And don’t get me started on the stupid Amazon Unlimited Music HD promos they bribe you with and then act like they never existed. Out of 10 million songs, only a small hand full are 24 bit quality sound. And they charge you on separate days for the HD. The Unlimited plan isn’t lumped together with HD. WTF! It’s all jacked up. Spotify premium is still the winner when it comes to sound quality. I’m a loyal Amazon customer. I’m confident Echo Studio next year will be the one to buy. Good luck =)
title: YOU’LL THANK ME LATER

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: tyrone
content: I wanted this speaker as soon as it was released. I mentioned to a close friend how excited I was about this this addition to the echo family. He surprised me and bought it for my birthday!! I added it to my smart tv with the fire stick.wow!!! I only have the one studio speaker and the sound is great. I have read reviews that say to get excellent theater sound you should have 2 studio speakers/sub woofer yet with my high ceiling and open space 1 speaker is more than great. If I added more speakers my neighbors would kill me 😂😂 My home is complete,2 echoes,3 echo dots and the echo studio speaker(grouping is key when you have this many echoes). I might get another echo dot(3rd gen). Thank Amazon for the Echo Studio Speaker and my friend 😂😂🙏🏽🙏🏽🙏🏽💕
title: The Speaker That will change Evening 🎉🎉

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: HTD
content: This is a nice speaker and a great value as an alternative to an Echo in a bedroom or kitchen or especially, in a multi-room setup.  It has everything the new Echo has with better sound and it's only a fifty dollars upgrade (provided you get the hub in both). So the difference in sound quality is well worth it. But understand it's limitations and advantages before you buy one. I bought 2 Studios and set them up as a stereo pair and the sound get's loud and it stays clear. I compared them to my Definitive Tech speakers and okay, not even close, the $1000 Def's blew them away. But that's a 600 premium.  So, let's compare them to my sons HomePods at 300. Much closer comparison. But still, the HomePod's clarity and sound stage win but not by much. But usually you're either in the Apple or Amazon ecosystem so not really relevant. Then I put them next to the new Echo's and at normal volume the Studio win's in both clarity and bass. The Echo's bass is way too boomy (although the sounds not bad in the new Echo) and that affects the clarity. At louder volumes, the Studio's crush. And it's only $50 more, if both have hubs, however even if you compare it to the $99 Echo it's well worth the upgrade. But remember, it's a substitute for an Echo not a dedicated home theater or music. As for the sound, it's spacious. It fills the room and provides a deep listening environment. However, that does effect the focus. It's hard to identify precisely where instruments are coming from (even when paired in stereo) but to get big, deep sound, that's a problem with all lower-end speakers. The clarity is amazing, no bass boom here. Even fine wind instruments are clearly heard. This was for me the aspect that stood out. Too many speaker makers tend to over-emphasize the bass (Sonos!). But that's what sells to many customers. It seems like Amazon didn't fall into that trap. That's not to say it lacks bass but its not overwhelming. If you want big boom, use an equalizer.  So overall I like the sound, especially for a bedroom but don't buy it for GREAT sound. You can do better with 400, but you'll give up the convenience of Alexa and a hub. Pairing 2 in stereo improves the sound but not to the point it can compete with most dedicated systems so I don't see the point. Yes, it improves the depth and gives better imagining then one but is it really a main listening system worth $400? Especially when you can't play 5.1 and the optical input won't split to allow stereo from an outside source? It doesn't improve the sound to the point it can compare with the sound or function book shelf speakers. Remember you're paying for Alexa and a hub where speaker makers are putting the money into better speakers. Get two put them in different rooms and enjoy what it does best, multi-room music and have Alexa in 2 rooms. The issue when considering these for a Home Theater system or as a replacement for a soundbar is that they ONLY play with content that comes through the Amazon Fire. That's a problem. Want to replace your sound bar with these? Well not if you have cable, a game system or DVD and don't want mono sound. I know wires are so 2000 but not when you have content from another source without physically connecting and disconnecting the input each time. Especially when the studio's sound can't play stereo let alone compete with a 5.1 or 7.1 system when you use the optical input. So where do these excel?  First - In a multi-room setup this is a great system. You can buy 10 Studio's and still be paying for the wiring of a traditional multi-room set-up. And it would sound great. No doubt, this is a huge positive. Second - In an apartment where you want better sound, have a soundbar for TV and a smaller space to fill with sound. And lastly, if you are considering a new Echo or Echo Plus. For a little more $ you can get better sound and Alexa. In the end, anywhere you want better sound and Alexa makes this a nice upgrade.
title: Good upgrade from an Echo but otherwise, limited.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Robert M.
content: I'll get the conclusion out the way: The speaker sounds surprisingly great For context, I own 2 Sonos One speakers and an Apple Homepod. I've always been lukewarm on the Sonos as their sound, while fairly good, doesn't match their price in my opinion. The Homepod, too, has always felt overpriced if not a decent sounding speaker. When the Echo Studio was announced, I figured I'd give it a shot given I could always send it back with Amazon's excellent return policy if it didn't live up to snuff. $200 put it below the Homepod and right around the Sonos One pricepoint so my expectations were set around there. Setup was simple as the device came pre-linked with my Amazon account. It goes through an initial room test where it plays some tones to measure the size and placement within the room (something it does continually should you move it around anyway). After that, all that was left was to listen to some music. I started with some Sinatra to get a feel for the vocals, and was immediately impressed with the tone & clarity. You could easily pick up on the subtle percussion on the background and the band hits packed a punch when they came in behind him. Next I tried some classical to get a feel for the range and, again, came away impressed. You could feel the lows of the brass section just as well as the high strings. The material was all represented well. Ok, so how about something that thumps. I asked Alexa to play some Chemical Brothers and this is where I got really impressed. Too many speakers, in my opinion, emphasize the volume of bass over accuracy. You end up with a boomy sound that doesn't reflect the music properly. Not the Echo Studio. The bass was punchy, loud and accurate. I tried some Daft Punk and Deadmau5 and came away equally impressed with the tight bass and crisp highs. Next I tried some Metallica. I feel if there's a critique I'd have with the Echo Studio it'd be here. The mid guitars lack a little feel and all start to sound a bit muddied together. You get the bass, you get the highs, but the guitars lack a little range. This isn't at all uncommon on speakers like this (the Sonos are quite bad in this regard in my opinion), but it could definitely be better). I tried a handful of the 3D audio selections on Amazon Music. In short, you do get a wider soundstage which is interesting, but you lose something in the clarity of the music. It feels a little gimmicky maybe, but not necessarily in a bad way. Just an "I don't know if this is actually an improvement or not" kind of way. In short, I'm very, very impressed with the Echo Studio. It's priced right at $200, has tighter and more accurate bass than the Homepod and a much fuller range than the Sonos One. If you're looking for a good speaker for music (with the bonus of having Alexa built in), I can't recommend this one enough. I came in skeptical. I came away impressed.
title: Fantastic sounding speaker that'll have me selling my Sonos & Apple Homepod.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Pretty Handy
content: Nice product from amazon, well built hardware, setup was fast.  Sound quality is poor,  I am hoping this will change soon. As with other Echo devices you cannot Android Cast to the device.  You can only cast from the amazon music app, or use bluetooth. This really is a nice speaker.  The sound quality is poor because of the tone balancing software (equalizer) deficiencies. The device control software only has a three band EQ.  This "studio" device needs more refinement than 3 bands.  The stereo separation enhancement sounds unrealistic. I turned this off and it sounds much more natural. I ran the setup routine several times with the device in different locations.  It just sounds like a cheap boom box. I did do the setup calibration in its current location and ran it for several days before I wrote this review. This is just not that good with the current software.  I would not recommend it and I will not buy another one unless the software (setup calibration and/or echo control) gets much better. Had to get it from Best Buy with free overnight shipping, because of amazon delay on shipping, for some reason it would not arrive until December.
title: Nice hardware, poor audio software.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Eunoias Orenda
content: The Amazon Echo 3d Studio speaker will NOT work in tandem with your existing surround home theater.  We have a Klipsch 5.1 speaker setup, Marantz A/V receiver.  BE AWARE.  You CANNOT treat this speaker as an additional speaker nor add it as a 'soundbar'.  I do NOT recommend this Echo Studio 3d.  Your existing surround sound system will NOT output sound alongside the Studio 3d speaker.  It is one or the other.  4+ hours on phone with Amazon tech support.  Purchased the 2nd generation Fire Cube plus the 3d Studio speaker.  Both going back tomorrow, sadly.  Especially disappointed having ordered this and waited over a month before it was released.  Disconnected our Bose surround and replaced with Kipsch.  Four days with the boxes sitting on the table, just making sure all was up to date.  We also have a Sony Bravia 4k Ultra 80 or so inch TV, etc.  Best equipment my middle-America fam can afford and thought this would be a great addition versus adding 2 Dolby Atmos speakers (like our basement home theater) due to more furniture in our main living room vs. basement.
title: Amazon Echo 3D Studio Speaker Does NOT work with your existing surround system.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Ankit Potdar
content: It doesn't play music. I tried both Amazon Music Unlimited HD and Spotify. It would repeat my command but will do nothing after that. When paired with Fire TV Stick 4k ( this creates a speaker group in the Alexa app), the tv audio works but basic standalone device functionality (play music) is broken till I I unplug and replug the device. I tried this with the TV on and off; it made no difference.
title: Doesn't respond to music request, great sound quality.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: christian v arriaga
content: Had been waiting a long time for this to finally arrive. Got it the day it was released. Was super excited that it arrived quickly. First thing you’ll notice is that is actually a very heavy speaker, bulky as well, if you compare it to the previous echo plus. Set up was simple enough through Alexa app. This speaker sounds great when is on full blast, but when you put it at a lower volume setting it disappoints. You can hear static, (kinda like a microphone when is on). When you turn it up it goes away. But I’m hoping that they can update it or somehow fix it. I really wanted to love this speaker, but was let down and I almost returned it right away but I figured I’d give it a shot for it to adapt to my room. Overall, the sound is crisp as it gets louder, and bass is great! That is one thing that this speaker has going on. The bass is awesome!  Hopefully there’s an update to get rid of static, otherwise I will be returning .
title: Wanted to love it

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Gaye
content: Bought this from Best Buy so didn't have to wait until December release. Wanted it to listen to high resolution music. It fits the bill. Alexa app. needs some work. Tech support is terrible.  They don't know much about the product other than what they read on cue cards. Also, now Amazon interrupts music streams with their own commercials. Trying to sell Audible Books. 😡 Like the speaker enough to keep it.
title: Good Enough.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Lynn S.
content: Great sound, especially with hd music. Microphones work better than any echo I've had. A friend with hundreds of dollars worth of sonos was blown a way by the sound of this speaker for the price! I will be getting another to replace a second gen echo in my bedroom.
title: Great sounding speaker.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: baton
content: I have a Sony 2-channel  amp with a pair of Polk audio Series 40 speakers in a small "Sun Room" just off a rather large veranda.  The amp also powers a pair of Polk audio outdoor speakers on the veranda. Common streaming device is a humble Amazon Dot.  My problem is the outdoor speakers require too much push to play both A and B. "A" gets too loud. So I turn A off and have setup a pair Echo Studio. (As I have several Amazon Echo devices around the house I usually stream to my "everywhere" group. It isn't a good solution. The Echo Studios are nearly as good as my Polk speakers, but not quite. The Echo Studio's strength is in filling a room alone. They're more impressive that way. And they are only a fourth the size of my Polk speakers. Now since I can play both, my Sun Room can ROCK! I'll eventually find another A/B volume solution and will cheerfully separate the Amazon Studio devices to another areas. They are worth the extra $ compared to the Echo 2nd Gs I have.
title: Comparison to traditional stereo.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Mick J
content: Read all the 'POSITIVE' reviews and then BUY IT.  I have noticed that with the negative reviews, which of there are not that many compared to the positive....Im seeing that those folks are doing something wrong, or trying to do something it was not meant to do.  Im one of those ' Audiophile ' types... very very picky about what I hear, how I hear it..etc.  When it was done setting up...which it did 99% of the work, I asked Alexa to play the best of 3D. First song up... Elton Johns ROCKET MAN.  Ok... Im gonna be a little wimpy here, but I swear...when the chorus kicked in, at volume 8.. I got a lump in my throat, and a shiver up my spine. What else is there to say.  OH.. and IGNORE then reviews that tell you to turn off the SPATIAL ENHANCEMENT .  No matter what you read....just leave it alone.  Leave it on.
title: I Love It.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: FrequentBuyer
content: Background: Have had Dots for years, but never played music through them obviously. Recently purchased an Echo 3 and was very impressed with the sound which seemed to defy the small size, and which prompted me to purchase a second Echo 3, so I would have music in a couple areas that did not have speakers. These Echo 3’s are perfect for spreading music that will sound great throughout the house, not sacrificing great sound. Echo Studio: Decided to take a chance with the mother of all Echoes, the Studio. Received it a couple days ago. Setup was a breeze. The speaker will appear in your app once it is shipped. Brilliant! I listen to a variety of types of music from pop to dance to classical. This speaker plays all of them well, though obviously tracks with a lot of bass bring this baby alive. Pandora tracks sound great. I haven’t used Amazon Music much.. until now. The HD & Ultra HD tracks are incredible, allowing me to hear the individual instruments while listening to classical music. That extra bit rate is worth the extra cost and what this Studio deserves. Would like a little more control with the equalizer, but it works, and maybe Amazon will give us a control to fine tune later. At 199.00, having experienced this speaker, it’s a nobrainer. I had been wanting the HomePod, but no way was I going to spend that amount on one speaker. Also, the Studio allows groups, multiple sources of music and easy to stream from your phone. Sonos & HomePod are more limited. I will definitely purchase another Studio at some point, if there is ever a sale, it will be even sooner. Support: As an aside, I applaud Amazon for having dedicated Alexa support, and staff that actually know the products. When I’ve had a question and able to get routed, the support is BRILLIANT... there’s that word again. Conclusion: Amazon, you’ve converted this Apple fan to an Echo fan & supporter for my home speaker needs. Brilliant!
title: Brilliant sound, simply brilliant speaker!

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Kunpeng Wang
content: I wouldn’t call myself an audiophile, but I love the sound aspect of all media formats. I have a Dolby-Atmos-enabled sound bar for my 4K UHD blu-ray movies and streaming devices, but because it’s designed for that purpose, it’s not the perfect speaker for only listening to music, even though it sounds great. Amazon Echo Studio is the first home smart speaker in the market that supports audio-only Dolby Atmos format via streaming. If you also happen to subscribe Amazon Music HD, you will have access to streamable music coded in Dolby Atmos format. Try the newly remastered (the one with the “3D” badge) Abbey Road by the Beatles, it sounds phenomenal: you could clear hear the depth and virtual placement of each instrument in your room. Like most single-unit Dolby Atmos products, however, you shouldn’t just place the speaker anywhere. Yes, they promote that the speaker will automatically adjust to the acoustics of any room, but it’d work the best in a place where there can be an equal distance to a wall on either side of it with minimal obstructions in between, a flat ceiling directly over it, and your primary listening location is directly in front of it. After all, single-unit Dolby Atmos products work by bouncing sounds off of ceiling and walls. Also, just like movies, the 3D effects of 3D music are only going to be as good as the sound mixers who have mixed them. Therefore, not all 3D music will sound as amazing as the remastered Abbey Road. Nevertheless, the speaker will still do a good job by maximizing any music source to take advantage of its 4-driver-1-woofer setup.
title: A Fantastic Sounding Smart Speaker

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: cam0453
content: I just got it today. Right away I can tell you it's very heavy and we'll made! The sound I thought would be better but saying that, it's better than a bosewave radio. I did find the aduio stopped on its own once. Overall it's worth upgrading from the echo secound Gen. I'm going to still pair with the sub because the bass could be better but I'm a audio nerd. Update! .....Second day of using it now. I'm disappointed in the sound quality I think my echo 2nd Gen sounds just as good, I really don't hear much difference in sound quality for example treble mid and bass but the sound is louder. I would wait until they come out with the 2nd Gen on this. I'm actually pissed off! I waited over a month for this and it sounds no better than the echo 2nd Gen. Update after a few weeks of use. Not worth it! If you have the echo 2nd generation don't upgrade the sound quality is not any better I think it's actually worse!
title: Not a 5 star yet, not even close!!

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Michael Walsh
content: First off let me say I own every echo product except the sub and the show 8. Having said that I was not sure what to expect when I bought the Echo Studio. I researched it pretty thoroughly before buying it. I am by no means an audio file although I do know what truly high end music reproduction sounds like. For the price the Echo studio is just what the doctor ordered. I was looking for something small and compact that would produce really good sound. The Echo Studio does just that. I have it placed on the bottom shelf of my entertainment center and the sound is fantastic. The microphones pick up my voice OK in that location, however as with all echo products, when placed near a TV  the microphones do not pick up my voice as well. I placed the Studio in another location for test purposes and found that the microphones were actually better than any other echo products I own. You can't go wrong with this speaker if you want good sound in a compact size.
title: Just what the doctor ordered

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: T-Rock
content: Update: After I posted my review, I was contacted by technical support. The rep did troubleshooting, with no success. I sent additional information over the next couple of days and did more testing. The rep called again and took some more readings to send to developers. Still no resolution and no additional information from technical support. They may be done with me. I no longer am using the Studio with my Fire TV Cube. The lag and getting it back on track again is too frustrating. It has been a waste of time and apparently $200 flushed down the toilet. Good thing I only bought one. I was going to buy another if it would work. ------------------- I was an early adopter and had postponed writing an honest review until now. I understand that early issues are usually fixed a few weeks later. But several months later and several contacts later there is no resolution to my issue. Technical support has been very unresponsive. I was told they were going to research my issue and get back with me and they never did. The last time I spoke with a rep, they sent a replacement. That did not help. The issue that I have is there becomes a video/voice synch issue after watching certain shows for a while. My set up is a Fire TV Cube and also an Amazon Recast DVR with the Echo Studio. To temporarily get rid of the synch issue, I have to restart the Fire TV Cube, but then there is no sound from the Echo Studio. So I have to unplug the Echo Studio and plug it back in. Then sound works again. Some days I have to do this more than once a day. As far as the sound system, when it works, the Echo Studio is great for movies and music, with a couple reservations. For music, the sound can be great. However, only some Amazon Music apps give you full quality. You don't get full quality from the Fire TV app, but I do from my phone app, or directly from the Echo Studio. For movies, the Echo Studio has good sound and a pair of them is much more immersive. However, two Echo Studios do not work as a pair when you are playing a movie through a disc player (I have a Samsung 4k bluray player). Only one Echo Studio works (The one with the cable into the player). The quality of picture and sound is better when playing a 4k disc versus streaming, but unfortunately sound only plays through one Echo Studio. So, months later there are still too many issues and limitations. I would not recommend at this point.
title: Months later too many issues and limitations

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Pierce
content: I had my doubts. What is 3D sound? I decide where I would put this. It wound up where our Bose 500 speaker was, in the living room. We plugged it it. It connected to my Netgear WiFi without any help. Assuming it talked to the other Alexas. Then it mapped the room, deciding on the best sound for that room. In one way, it is a bigger Alexa, doing everything my other Alexas do. "Alexa, play 3D." first song up happened to be the new Beatles digital version of "Something." It was great. Next, the teenager said, "Alexa, play hip hop." I don't know the song but the kid approved. Then mom. "Alexa, play 3D dance music." Big approval. "You can remove the Bose." Full house approval. We all love it. The sound is incredible. It is now the Alexa around which our house revolves. Highly recommended.
title: Takes Music, and Alexa to the Next Level

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: KathyH
content: I’m on my second Studio and have yet to be wowed. The sound is definitely better than the regular Echo but I’m having a variety of connectivity issues. To compare, I had the HomePod for a short time before seeing info of the pending Studio release. When I first turned on the HomePod, its sound wowed me! I didn’t experience the same wowness the first time I heard the Studio. First thing to know, which isn’t mentioned anywhere, connect Studio to your 2.4mHz network and not 5.0. Also, connect directly to your router and not through an extender. I discovered this by chance while troubleshooting connectivity problems (none of the agents thought to ask and I happened to bring it up). Not sure what you do if your Studio is upstairs and your router is downstairs and the direct signal is weak. I returned the Studio and got a Bose 500 speaker. It sounds so much better but it’s a bit glitchy with Alexa. Arg!
title: Studio has been very buggy

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Malcolm Granger
content: I have all Echo models including an Echo Gen.2 stereo pair. and could wait to try the Studio. Here are my first impressions. It is larger than the HomePod and really likes to be played LOUD. At very low volumes, it is less impressive. Regardless of what anyone says, no solo speaker can match the spatial environment of a stereo pair. I may wait for a second Studio around the holidays, when it might be cheaper (hint, Amazon, hint...). I had several frustrations. First is the availability and sound of the '3D' effect from Amazon Music. I could barely find any valid '3D' music outside of 5-6 3D Amazon Playlists (which all seemed to include the same very few songs). I count maybe 20 in total? If there are more, then I could not find them. C'mon Amazon, if you are all in on 3D, then start adding these! ...and there is the rub. Few songs, no new being added lately that I can find, and the complete lack of knowing if you are playing a 3D song or not. No badge labeling on the track, no clear listing of the 3D or not, and worse, if it is being played for reals, then I could not hear any difference (!). It all makes me think the Studio is not playing in the 3D mode or not. In fact, as many have noted here, the sound is more bright and present when the 3D (spatial enhancement) is turned off! I am so afraid that the '3D' mode will die a quick death and no one would even know. I would love to even be able to compare '7 Rings' with and without the 3D effect, but how can anyone know which is which without any clear labeling of the track. At this rate, the Studio will become just a 'big Echo' and all the 3D promise will be abandoned.
title: Where's the 3D difference? Where is the magic?

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Carlo Dixon
content: I am a audiophile with not that much money and let me tell you, I have had B & W Speakers which sounded great!!!  I currently have 2 Sony SRX-88's and  1 SRX -99 which sound awesome too especially the 99 because it has alot of the missing low end that the 88's are missing.  I figured I would try the Echo Studio because of the 3d Music... and I have to say I am IMPRESSED.  I believe that these speakers sound better than the Sony's which is a pretty high bar.  I agree that the Studio is the best sounding Echo speaker... but I believe that is really low bar, considering that the other speakers seem to be to get a audio assistant to the market... which I believe that Amazon has done a great job in doing that.  The things that I really like about this speaker is that it is a true audiophile speaker, great frequency range even in the low end.  I think as a assistant it works alot better then the other Amazon speakers (it understands when your talking to it), Even when not listening to a 3d track it sounds 3d because the spatial enhancement it provides depth, it is relatively small with a huge sound 330 watts, without distortion... if you have this speaker try listening to Beyonce's Homecoming Album with the Volume turned up ALOT!!!  If that doesn't move you... you can't be moved!!
title: Best Echo Speaker, How about Best Speaker I have heard under a Grand!!!

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: ChicagoSteve
content: I was an early adopter and have had a echo V1 since they first came out. The sound quality on the Studio is a 10X upgrade to that and it's mics are soooo much better. If you want really great, room filling sound, give the studio a try. At this price compared to the competition, you won't regret it
title: Major Upgrade

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Lionel Gautreaux
content: Amazon really SCREWED up on this product. The sound below level 5 is just about awful. Giving more power to the smaller speakers at the lower volumes seems to be a very simple process, but they didn't do it. Also, the microphones on on TOP of the enormous speaker instead of the sides. So, since the volume has to be above five, you have to scream at the ceiling in order to be heard. They had a chance to beat the living tar out of the competition but left some serious flaws on the table. I should have waited for second generation but oh well. UPDATE: I really HATE that the microphones are on top of the device. DO NOT buy this until Amazon fixes this serious freaking issue. One year after buying this piece of junk, it won't stay connected to my network. All off my other Echo devices work just fine. JUNK. JUNK. JUNK.
title: Good but has major suck parts.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: JJFlash
content: Another Update:  I really want to emphasize that recent software updates have completely solved the problems people were reporting with the Stereo Spatial Enhancement setting. This speaker sounds phenomenal and I can't wait to get a second one for stereo pairing. Unfortunately, I waited too long to order during Prime Days so I won't get until just before Christmas. I've decided to hold off on getting the Echo Sub until after I've experienced two Studios paired together. Update: Changed from 4 to 5 stars. I had followed other reviewers recommendations and turned the Stereo Spatial Enhancement setting off. Big mistake for my tastes. I understand that everyone has different preferences, but when I finally turned this stetting on the improvement in sound quality was immense. I figured out that when this setting is off, the top firing midrange speaker and the front firing tweeter are silenced. No idea why. When this setting is on, all speakers are producing sound, and it is pretty great. I'm now ordering a second Echo Studio to try out the stereo pairing. I'm still think the bass could be better and will probably add an Echo Sub whenever they're available again. I really wanted to love this speaker, but that's not really the case. It certainly sounds good, but not as good as I'd hoped. I don't really listen to music at a high volume very often, and at the low to moderate volume levels I usually listen to I find the Echo 3rd generation to be more enjoyable. Now, when I do want to play something loud, the Echo Studio is great. It can get very loud and never distorts. It does require considerable tweaking of the very limited equalizer features to get the best sound. The default settings are lacking in the bass department. Once you find the settings that are right for you it sounds good. All in all it's a very good speaker, but unless you listen at higher volumes often, the Echo 3rd generation is a more affordable choice. My music tastes, by the way, are hard rock, classic rock, and some metal (Slayer, etc).
title: Very Great

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Ryszard Kilarski
content: I am... disappointed. First, the good: The sound is great, it fills the room very well and, as you expect, setup and folding it into the Alexa ecosystem is a breeze. But I certainly have a lot of criticisms. I'm using this as a speaker for my TV, and HERE is where it just falls down hard. So here are all my problems and complaints: 1. When I use it as an Alexa home theater group for my 4K Fire Stick, it constantly disconnects when I pause my video. Even when it works, I lose maybe 10 seconds of sound before it reconnects. But when I pause video for "too long", it doesn't reconnect for... well, I've sometimes waited 30 seconds to a minute before giving up and having to re-do my home theater group. Once I redo my home theater group (basically, just editing the existing home theater group, unselecting and reselecting the Studio, and clicking save) then it seems to work. Until my next pause. This is hella frustrating. This happens A LOT. The long pause to reconnect happens almost each time, and having to redo my home theater group is maybe every other day. I can't help but compare to my Sonos speakers (in a different home) where I can't even tell it's on Wifi, it "just works". 2. So, instead, I tried connecting to the TV directly with an audio cable because my thinking went: if it's directly connected, then maybe it won't do that pause and certainly maybe it won't drop completely. Nope, same thing. It's as if it's ignoring the direct connection and still using wifi for sound. 3. Alright, so I switched to using an Apple TV instead of the Fire Stick. MUCH better: The reconnect time goes down to maybe a few seconds and it hasn't dropped at all. BUT now that I'm using Apple TV, I can't control the volume with my Fire Stick remote. So either I have to do it via voice or the physical buttons (what is this, the 80's?). 4. Now it's definitely better (but it's frustrating that it works better when NOT using the Fire Stick!). But lastly, the wake functionality seems to be significantly over-sensitive. We're watching something, and maybe we make a sound or just move on the couch (not even words) and the Studio mutes the video sound and listening to a command from us. It's just tooo sensitive and interrupts our viewing a lot. I'd like to try to turn off the microphone while watching TV, but then I can't use voice to change the volume! Ugh! 5. Finally, ever since I plugged it into the TV via a hardwire, it seems to reboot a lot. Like, two or 3 times a week. This is not good either. Yes, I've reset it, I've re-paired it, I've examined my network (I'm a tech person) and it all points to the Studio.
title: Great sound, but so many bugs and problems!

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Steve is not my name...
content: Update: put two of them together and it's the best soundbar for a TV you can buy. I have no clue how all these reviews are having problems with pairing and creating groups and so on and so forth first of all. I have a ton of echo devices and they all play nice with the Studio. I've had Samsung soundbars, 5.1 surround sound systems, and have been around the Sonos Beam and Playbar. All I can say is this thing ROCCCKKKKKSSSSS. The sound is incredible. Absolutely incredible. It as a stand alone speaker blows away any similarly priced sound bar or speaker for music and even TV watching. Sorry for those of you who overpaid for the Sonos playbar as well, because it rivals that at a third of the cost. The Atmos sound is incredible on a single unit hooked up through my 4k Fire Stick, but one unit isn't enough for the ultimate experience. So, I just ordered a second one to go on each side of the TV. (While it sounds amazing by its onesy, you really should pair them if you're going to use them for a TV setup. That was not my original intention when bought but I was so happy with it now I just have to.) Amazon really knocked this out of the park. I was iffy on the sound from the new gen Echos and not very happy with the sound for price really, so I was hesitant on expectationsfor the Studio. (I have two echos and like 8 dots....and Echo Autos, and Echo buds.....yeah I'm a slave to Amazon at this point....), but the Studio just killed the competition. Sorry Sonos. Will update if necessary when I get the second one. If it wasn't for the Mrs. hating too much bass I would pair it with the Echo sub, but this thing has enough bass on its own. Cant wait to get the second one, pair them, and condemn the sound bar to the garage...... Now, let's get working on a complete surround system with this same bang for the buck Amazon. Chop chop.
title: Love.......it.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: stevethrewup
content: I'm pleased with the sound of this echo, but there is an issue with the mini-toslink input.  If this input is being used and the echo switches to a call or drop-in, the mini-toslink input doesn't return when the call is finished.  Unplugging the mini-toslink and plugging back in does no good.  You need to unplug the echo power and plug it back in to continue using the port.  I'm hopeful this will be fixed soon but will need to return it before it's too late.  I really needed the digital input for my use case.
title: Mini-toslink Input Issues

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: rodo
content: Lots of issues when synced with fire tv cube. -sometimes when using with tv, and a notification comes through or I ask Alexa a question, the tv sound stops playing when the notification is done playing.  I have to pause the tv program and restart it in order to get tv sound back. -sometimes tv programs on amazon prime will start to play in fast forward with the voice is at normal speed. -sometimes the tv program will be about 10 seconds off of the voice -sometimes when I turn the tv off or stop a tv program, the soundtrack of that tv program keeps playing until I shut the tv down or start a different program.  If I ask Alexa to "stop," she wants to play some song with "stop" in the title. I have had the same fire cube for well over a year (2?) and never had any of these issues until I got the echo studio and synced it. Update 2.15.20 lowering from two to one star. all issues previously mentioned continuing. also, usually, when I am closest to the studio, it will not respond to my voice commands, instead, one of my other, further away devices respond.  When the device in the other room responds, I can hardly hear the response because it is so far away.  for example, this evening i was standing two feet from the studio, with the wake word, the echo dot upstairs responded.  the studio is the worst amazon device i have ever purchased.  Additionally, when I am in an area farther away from the studio, and use the wake word, instead of the closest device responding, the studio will respond. Update 3.27.20  Continue to have most of these problems, esp all problems with TV playback.  In addition, the Studio suddenly stopped working with Audible.  It simply ignores without any response any Audible requests.  This device is still overall a POS.
title: Lots of issues - udpate lowering rating from 2 to 1 star.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: James Hughes
content: I purchased the Echo Studio expressly for the purpose of using it as a home theater speaker with my Fire TV Cube.  Unfortunately I’ve passed my 30 day return window, otherwise I’d be sending the Studio back. In my experience, it fails miserably as a home theater speaker, and if your considering purchasing the Studio for that purpose - look elsewhere. Setup of the speaker is just as easy as setting up any Echo device using the Alexa app.  The demo was encouraging because the sound quality right off the bat was impressive. Setting up a home theater system and paring the speaker with the Fire TV Cube was easy as well, but it was all down hill from there.  At first, there was a noticeable lip sync delay.  There is a section in the Fire TV audio settings to adjust for any delay, but it seemed that I had to make that adjustment at least once a day, sometimes multiple times after switching between apps like Netflix and Hulu. Starting about a week ago, we couldn’t any sound out of the Fire TV after turning it on. After a combination of rebooting the Cube and power cycling the Studio, we’d get sound, but the lip sync delay appeared even worse. Sometimes I’ve had to reset the network settings for the Studio in the Alexa app because it seemed like the Fire TV Cube couldn’t connect to the device, even though both were on the same wifi network.  Finally, today, after dealing with the connectivity issues once again, I deleted the home theater feature from Alexa and hooked my Fire TV Cube to a Sonos Beam.  Even though the sound isn’t as good (it’s still really good), the connectivity issues are gone. Since I’m past the return window, I may try to offload the Studio on eBay. Otherwise I’m stuck with a moderately expensive Echo device that will never get used again.
title: Sounds great - reconsider using it as a home theater speaker with Fire TV Cube

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Bendy (Ben and Randy)
content: We had 2 Sonos One speakers for a few years now, and TBH we've loved them in terms of sound quality... but their Alexa integration, however was lacking in one critical feature - being able to join the Alexa "everywhere" group for when we had parties or are doing things around the house. We like to be able to move room to room and have the same music... it's just nice to be able to clean and jam out house-wide. We do the same for parties - lower music in every room is so much nicer than loud music in a few areas. This closes the bridge a bit between normal Alexa's (not great sound) with the Sonos Ones (great sound with tech limitations). The one big downfall is that this is 1.5x as big, approximately, as the Sonos One. Had we had the Sonos:1 instead, we'd have just gotten some Echo Input devices and called it a day, but they made these without input ports, so that was off the table as well. Let's talk about cost - full price currently is VERY expensive - more than the Sonos devices. If the Alexa integration isn't important to you, go with the Sonos model - smaller profile, still works great, etc. I'd not spend the extra on the Sonos One - just get the Sonos:1 or the Sonos:5
title: Comparable to Sonos One sound in a much larger footprint

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: anon
content: tl;dr: Excellent Bluetooth and Wifi speaker for home music, audiobooks, and lectures, with minor static noise. I've wanted a speaker for a few years.  I've upgraded my other listening devices (Oppo PM3 planar magnetic headphones, and AirPods Pro), but I've waited to get a speaker for my TV, or MacBook, and my life.  I read all the reviews for the Bose, Google, and Apple products, and I ended up getting the Sonos One.  Sonos was an excellent brand, but after getting the Sonos One (Gen 2), it just wouldn't set up with my home's wifi.  I tuned the wifi, reset the wifi, and changed my wifi password, all to no avail.  So I shipped the Sonos One back for a refund, and waited a few weeks until the (conveniently) Echo Studio came out.  I had high hopes, although I had gotten an Echo Dot in the past that never paired to wifi either. Anyways, the Echo Studio paired to my home Wifi with ease, and paired to my MacBook Pro with ease.  It also came in a gorgeous container like Mac products.  The sound quality is great; I'm still fully assessing it, but it compares well with my PM-3 headphones.  I just wanted an audiophile-like speaker that could play music, Audible audiobooks, and lectures from my professors, and this delivers.  I've never used Alexa before; I just want basic Alexa functionality to tell it to play some mood music for house guests, and it looks like it can do that.  The Echo Studio just has this weird static in the background.  It was very noticeable; then I reset the device, and it's still perceptible if I turn the audio way down, but it's very minor.  Maybe I'll call tech support on a rainy day.  Overall, very satisfied!
title: awesome bluetooth and wifi speaker with minor static noise

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Blindman
content: First, I have a 2nd gen Echo, Echo Dots, Echo Input, Echo Auto, Fire TV 4k, many devices controlled by Alexa and subscribe to Amazon Music HD. That being said, I was overly optimistic about the Echo Studio. I was hoping to replace the Echo in my kitchen with a better sounding speaker. Although a Denon receiver in the family room (open to the kitchen area) takes full advantage of Amazon Music HD, the convenience of the Echo tucked away in a corner on top of the cabinets makes it the most used audio component in the house. It's on for much of the day while listening to Sirius XM, Pandora or Amazon Music. Now for the good, the bad and suggestions for Amazon. The good: - It worked out of the box and was effortless to set up (other than with the Fire TV 4k). - Was reasonably attractive and solidly built. - The bass response went fairly deep and sounded good on the right material. - It had enough power to sound "punchy" when it needed to. The bad: - The 3D effect was non-existent to my ears. I tried the speaker in four different locations (even though is was destined to be in the kitchen). - The sound quality was not pleasing on most material. This could potentially be corrected if the EQ was expanded from three-band to ten-band. While determining this, I gave the most weight for sonic quality to songs delivered in Ultra HD from Amazon Music since the Sirius XM material is pretty compressed. - The volume level was never quite right when using the 1 -10 scale. Even using the Alexa app to control it was a pain. Sometimes it did not remember the setting when exiting the app. I don't understand why Amazon can't expand the volume option to either 1 - 100 percent or allowing .5 settings (i.e. "Alexa: Set the volume to 2.5", or "Alexa: Set the volume to 25%" ). This also hold true for the Echo speaker (as others have voiced online). For my needs, 2.5 or 3.5 (depending on time of day and the music source) are perfect, but going into the Alexa app to change it is not convenient. - I could not get it to work with the Fire TV 4k. - The spatial enhancement for stereo music is awful. Just turn it off immediately (it is only available with the latest update for the Alexa app). - As noted by another reviewer, the blue light is not visible is many placements like it is on the standard Echo. I tried using the audible notification (available in the settings), but it was obnoxious. My suggestions for Amazon: - Make the EQ ten bands, not three - Add more granularity to the voice activated volume adjustments. - Market it as a full range Alexa enabled speaker with an included hub - not a "surround sound" speaker where it fails miserably. Sell that as a bonus feature. - Improve the quality of the high frequencies. Not sure if it's the tweeter or the amp, but the high end could use some help to produce a more pleasing sound. I returned it after one week... but would likely have kept it if it had the expanded EQ and ability to voice control the volume in finer increments.
title: Needs a few tweaks

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Jarvis
content: Won’t play music when paired with fire tv on Samsung 9000 tv.  Why is this?  It does play music if the fire tv is on and select amazon music. But won’t play music when tv is off.  Using 3  wiFi 6 ROG Asus routers and 2 AC routers set up in mesh network. Switched to all new cat 8, high speed  HDMI  and coax cables. Got a call from tech which was nice but no solution as of yet. Going to try to pair with a cube to see if that works.
title: Wont play music when paired with fire tv

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Jessicca
content: Over all this speaker is amazing. I have a Sonos before this and wanted something with more Alexa features as well as well rounded sound. None of the other Amazon speakers were as good as Sonos in audio quality. I played with a demo of this in Best Buy before I pre-ordered this. And I have no regrets. My ONLY problem is I prefer Apple Music and she doesn’t play the best all the time with it. Sometimes I’ll be randomly disconnected and have sign in again. The speaker itself is incredible.
title: Well rounded sound

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: O.Bqwiet
content: I was a little reluctant to buy this due to the conflicting reviews on sound quality, but knowing Amazon had a good return policy I figured I'd try it out. Are they the best speakers in the whole world? No. Are they the second best speakers in the whole world? No. But they're pretty good speakers nonetheless. I'd them a 5 for set up, versatility and ease-of-use. And far as sound quality probably a 4.5. The only thing I have to compare them to are my edifier 1000's. And although I like the edifier's better, this speaker's sound quality is not that far off from them.  I mainly wanted the speaker to put in the living room and I really like that I can group it with my family room edifier speakers (that are hooked up to an echo Dot through a cable) and the sound is loud and clear throughout the house. On their own I think they would benefit from having a sub paired to two of them, but a single unit still sounds really good. One other reason for not giving them a five is that I just can't believe that these are 330 Watts. I would guess more like 90 to 100 Watts, but they're loud enough none the less. I also tried it outside for a bit and I know they are loud enough to irritate your neighbors if that's what you want. Over All I'm happy with my purchase and I would recommend them.
title: Beauty is in the ear's of the beholder, I guess.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: J. Wo
content: This Echo Studio replaced a 1st generation Echo in my dining room. So setup was easy. Compatible with other Echo devices, lights, thermostat, etc in our home. The improved 3D sound quality is immediately noticeable! This is a great audio solution for a small condo like ours. No long wires or multiple speakers to hang on walls. Just plug & play. Excellent sound fills the space. But well-balanced bass, to not shake up the condo neighbors. A+.
title: Great sound!

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Nicholas Cultrara
content: I am so happy I went with  an Amazon Echo Studio to replace my 13 year old soundbar (had to give it away because of a high pitched whine emanating even when shut off, drove me crazy while trying to sleep). I was going to get a soundbar system for twice the price. With this device I have less wires, one less remote, plus Alexa. Was watching my favorite scenes from the Star Wars movies to test it out and I was blown away. Keep in mind I have it plugged in through the optical port on my tv so it functions as a soundbar, but in that regard it is an excellent device. Music and podcasts sound great as well. Of course this will not satisfy someone who requires the full blown theatre experience but for the price and  lack of messy cables and wire, one can't go wrong if they want to enhance weak tv speakers. Highly recommended!!!
title: Incredible Device considering its tiny size!!!

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Ronald Thompson
content: Update: After what feel is unnecessary investigations online, and turning off the awful stereo spatial audio setting which is on by default, the quality and lost layers issue was resolved and general music sounded much better - and at a lower volume - making Alexa’s quiet voice less of an issue. However this hits the 3D audio files a bit as they sounded, less ideal than they would have otherwise. I’m not going to bounce in and out of the app for this setting. Also there's no way this setting should be on by default with it in the state it is currently in. Inexcusable to not screen all formats/genres of music before pushing out a device with a feature that is not advertised. Alexa’s voice on this device, however (as well as comms) is still far too low. We still need the ability to set these independently from one another if there is going to be these kinds of balancing issues depending on the device type. Was going to provide a slight bump to the score, but this is still bothersome however that using as a basic Alexa device is hamstrung by the audio mixing. A good quality for the $ speaker that is just seemingly going to waste. —— I gave this a full on shot, tried various music types and the lot, and with many of the non-classical and traditional rock tracks, such as pop and electronic music, a lot of layers, elements, and specifically - vocals - were drowned out by the “rest” of the music. This even occurred in the 3D branded tracks, in where undoubtedly the vocal layer is far too squashed. It sounds great, it’s just uneven. Even Alexa’s voice itself is shockingly way too low compared to the music, and any call to another Echo device, is barely audible unless cranked up. If you have any intention of buying this as an Alexa speaker with improved audio - do consider the unbalanced nature of the audio itself. Overall this product is a disappointment. I also do not own a Fire TV Cube so I will never have the ambition to get a second for Dolby Atmos, unless it’s more broadly supported (which it is not). Maybe an update fixes it, I’ve received a few already, still have the balancing issues even when tinkering and putting it in a super ideal spot. I just can’t unhear the flaws.
title: Update: Disable Stereo Spatial, then it’s better as a solo unit. Still has audio balancing issues.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Arthur Mills
content: It's a solid speaker and a fair price.  I'm bound to the Alexa world and having a first class speaker available makes life easier.  I was able to connect this to my Fire TV 4k Stick and it took over for my TV speakers admirably (though this did take me messing with the LG HDMI settings to make it go).  The sound watching shows is far superior to the LG speakers, as you'd expect.  I ride a bike with a fan on during my show watching usually, so having this put out good sound above that is great. We watched a couple of old movies with it on and I saw a couple of Witcher episodes.  Sound works far better than any other Alexa device.  I have a Play 5 soundbar from Sonos and it's not as good as that, but you would not expect it to be given the $400 price difference.  It is solid sound, but not overwhelming sound. For a home theater setup I will probably pair another with this.  But I will almost certainly replace most devices in the house with these over time for very rich whole home audio.  In all at this price it's a worthy purchase. I bought on Oct. 29 and it just arrived yesterday, so Amazon needs to get the supply and demand thing figured out, but in all I can say I'm pleased.
title: If you're in the Alexa world this is the way to be.

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Steven Y.
content: I had high hopes for this, but with Amazon HD 3D music playing on perfect WiFi, I just can’t say there is anything special with the sound quality. Just did the latest firmware update, and that helped a little, and seemed to make the sound slightly better.  I definitely will not continue with Amazon Ultra HD subscription just for this, since it really is nothing special about the sound. Yes it’s better than the regular Echo, but the sound is directional with the tweeter only in the front.  For the large size, I would have expected better sound.
title: Directional Sound

product: Echo Studio - High-fidelity smart speaker with 3D audio and Alexa
author: Customer
content: I was excited to receive this but after listening to music on it for an hour, I'm returning it. There is very little bass or kick to the music, maybe I received a defective unit?
